author: cian riordan
content:
A tangent…

I’m lucky to have spent many years in a great studio with lots of great drums & gear… not to mention being mentored by one of the great engineers of our time. Having this perspective is massively useful in mixing other peoples tracks, because I feel I have a north star of what good drums can sound like if they’re recorded and performed properly. It used to be that my starting point for mixing drums were working with tracks that I had recorded myself… and most of the above problems were solved before the mix stage. These days, with smaller budgets and time constraints, its very rare that this is a possibility.

I’m including this drum tracking session from a few years ago that I recorded at Barefoot. It was for a project that Matt was producing that never saw the light of day. But we went all out with the drum setup in the big room, through the console, and had a great drummer. This might be useful for some people who have never gotten properly recorded drum tracks… to get a sense of how good thigns can sound before the ‘mix’ stage. These are the tracks that were printed into Pro Tools off of the console, and the three busses were prints of the outboard compressor busses we were using while monitoring. It’s unlikely these busses would get used in mixing, but they’re a good reference to what we were listening to in the room while we were tracking. But as you’ll notice, the individual drum blend can stand on it’s own two feet. Hopefully this is useful as well.

Thanks for coming to my Ted talk.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This. 10% skill, 90% people actually wanting to be around you.

No matter how well you know compression or eq, if you’re not in the room you can’t make the music. I remember asking producers I’d do whatever, clean toilets, coil cables. Just wanted to be in the room. It’s actually how I ended becoming a vocal producer… a producer I admired didn’t want to tune vocals anymore lol

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly, that line is a bit over blown. It’s more “oh the chorus is louder, let’s knock it back a click or two on the input so it doesn’t distort”

We were usually recording songs in fairly small sections, making sure to get the details right. There wasn’t a lot of jedi like fader riding. On very rare occasions if I knew there was going to be a huge dynamic shift I’d reach out and grab the output fader, but I can probably count on one hand how many times I’ve had to do that.

We were fairly conservative on the 1176 on the way in, largely cause you can’t un crunch a vocal that’s been over compressed, but once the vocal was in PT it would be hit by just irresponsible levels of compression and limiting. Like goes against how virtually every “expert” online would tell you how to do it. Most people would tell you the solo’d tracks would sound bad, but as part of the song their impact is objectively unarguable

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
.
Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively)

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level

author: Slow Hand
content:
It's a big topic, but gain staging is about finding the optimal amount of gain at every stage of the recording and mixing process.

Good gain staging allows you to get the best fidelity out of a recording by preventing things from creating unwanted distortion or amplifying unwanted noise. **OR** if you are *seeking* some distortion and compression it's about turning up the gain enough to give you the amount that you're seeking from your tools.

Gain staging is something to be considered at all steps of the production process. For example:

*1. How loud is an amplifier turned up in the room? Is the microphone being blow out by it?

2. How high is the gain on a microphone preamp and is it at risk of clipping if the performer plays loudly?

3. Is the gain so low that when I turn a signal up later on the noise floor will rise with it?

4. If I'm recording to tape, am I recording quiet enough that it won't saturate the signal, or do I want for the signal to slam the tape and be saturated?

5. How loud is an individual channel in a DAW? Is it making the channel clip?

6. How loud is a signal that's being sent into a piece of hardware or a plugin? Am I distorting the circuitry at all?

7. Is my signal coming in so hot that it makes a compressor react way too hard?

8. How loud is the entire track I'm mixing? Is the limiter crushing the dynamics in an unwanted way? Or am I hitting it just with just enough level to get a certain flavor of pumping and clipping?

9. Is my final mix going to hit digital zero and create unwanted clipping?*

So gain staging is not a single thing, but a series of choices that are made every step of the way around how you manage the "voltage" of your signals. Together these choices all add up to a mix that "breathes" well and is free of excessive or unwanted distortion.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I would rule out the Izotope production bundle (Ozone is fine). I think Izotope is the least musical and hit-or-miss of the options. It's not bad, but it's not as fun to use as the other options, and I think that has an effect on your results.

Both the FabFilter Mastering bundle and Soundtoys bundle are great and you wouldn't go wrong with either pick. But they occupy different niches: FabFilter is clean and surgical while Soundtoys is all about injecting vibe and coloration and doesn't include anything remotely surgical.

I guess if you can only pick one I'd start with Soundtoys for the vibe and the way it would expand the sonic palette for your production work. Your DAW is going to have some perfectly capable EQ's and compressors to tide you over until you're ready for FabFilter.

Put another way, your production work is upstream of your mixing work and will influence the sound of your records more.

author: MikeMillerMixes
content: Hey guys it’s not the panning that’s synced. It’s the pre delay for the reverb. The sound is sent to pairs of objects that are mapped to points in the room and each one has a different predelay so that it moves the room.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Great responses above. One other thing to conceptualize is guitar amps. Many guitar amps have built in spring reverb. If you mic that amp with a single mic, that mono signal has the reverb as a part of it. When you pan that complete signal, it carries a kind of depth and character that is very different from a stereo reverb or even a separate send. 

Mono elements with their own reverb can achieve an interesting spatial clarity that you can't get with eq or compression or whatever else you use to give elements their own place in a mix. I use it on all kinds of things from guitars to vocals to drums to whatever.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Nailed it Will. Split mono is a step in my mix prep sequence. Efficient method goes like this:

PT Downmixer stock plugin is the one for this (it collapses stereo channels to mono) - flip the phase of one side in the GUI and save that as your user default. If you insert your Downmixer on a faux stereo track, it’ll immediately silence it, so you can happily split and delete what you don’t need. 

(Check the meters though, sometimes ambience or other subtle stereo info isn’t very audible unless cranked.)

If the stereo track contains slightly panned mono information, pushing/pulling either of the faders in Downmixer will quickly get it to cancel, and you can note how much extra gain you need to add or subtract when level matching in the final step (below). Obviously if it’s deliberately panned info, you can either just leave the track stereo or match the pan position by ear (I prefer to do this because I like mono channels to behave like mono channels, and also half the CPU you’d use on a stereo track).

Finally, use clip gain to add 3dB to the resulting mono channel, and obviously pan it centre. This makes up for the level change according to default pan laws in Tools (-3dB).

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i love this question. i've been doing this for long enough that the cycles of how records sound has changed several times. so every few years i try and take some time to unlearn/relearn.

there's no good short answer, but i'd start with taking some time outside of mixing to just listen to records. whether you've done this before or not, get to know your speakers and your monitoring environment better than before. listen to your favorite records that you know well, and make some tweaks. you don't necessarily have to redo your whole setup, but listen to your speakers in slightly different positions, different settings on the back of the speaker, etc. and really dig into listening and enjoy yourself.

that's usually enough to make me think about mixes very differently (which ultimately means i get better when i re-incorporate most of the things i already know). but if you need more, just try and simplify. start a mixing by just leveling everything. clip gain and leveling and panning. then balance frequencies and compress (via compressor or saturator or limiter or whatever). basically, with fresh ears, go back to basics.

not sure if that will transform you into a new mixer, but that's an outline of an approach i use when i feel like i need a big talent upgrade

author: Slow Hand
content:
One thing I'd add is the importance of matching your output levels so that the dry sound and the compressed sound are the same volume when you bypass the compression. Many compressors have have automatic volume compensation included and others will require you to adjust the makeup gain that comes after the compression.

The reason it's important is because when we're comparing the dry signal to the compressed signal, the louder of the two signals will always feel better to us. It's important to match the volume levels when comparing so that we're not fooling ourself into thinking a louder signal is better and we can hear the compression (or most effects) for what really is.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: One of my fav ear excersizes is throwing a multiband compressor that will let you solo bands on your master/main output (compressor off, I like using gaffel, it lets you split the bands without imparting any actual processing), and listen to all of your favorite songs to see how the frequencies add up. What’s important below 80, below 120, below 300, etc. I have learned just how different so many of my favorite tracks are balanced, and also learned to identify those frequency areas by ear much faster

author: Deleted User
content: The biggest difference between multiband compression and dynamic EQ is having crossover filters vs EQ gain automation.  They may do similar things dynamic wise but the ways they select the areas to dynamically control are different.

author: cian riordan
content:
1) Yes! All MPDI-4 mic pres. Signal chain would have been Mic -> Pre -> UTA Console Line In -> Pro Tools.

2) I’m pretty sure this would’ve been a Frankenstein. Most likely Eric’s Sonor birch kick drum with a Remo Black Dot on it. Almost certainly Vistalite toms… and this sounds like a Bell Brass snare.

3) Room mics are placed probably 20 feet away, spaced wide, pointed at the kit. Eric would always point the room mics away from the drums with the cardioid null towards the drum kit, but I found I got more direct, punchy sounds with it facing the drums. Chamber mics would’ve been a foot apart, pointed 45 degs out… sort of intentionally phasey to make them wider.

4) Yeah, you’re onto it. The overheads are intentionally wide and close to the cymbals. The mono mic and close mics are doing the heavy lifting with the drums and the L/R OHs are almost just cymbal spot mics with some kit stereo information peppered in.

5) Saturation is a combination of driving the UTA pres, clipping the line input of the console, and trimming things back with the faders. Might’ve been an LA-2a on the snare with no compression, just crapping out the tubes.

Sorry wish I woulda taken pictures of this session. Dave Elitch was the drummer and he’s a fucking monster.

There are plenty of times that I’ll use a high pass on or above the fundamental frequency, depending on context. If I have 5 instruments all playing the same note, then chances are some of them want to live in different parts of the frequency range (maybe strummy guitars are more about the transients and first harmonics, for example). 

As everyone’s saying, if it sounds good it is good, but I wouldn’t overthink the note-to-frequency thing too much.

author: cian riordan
content: First I'll think about what the tonal impact will be. There are particular compressors that automatically suck low or high end out of the signal... and for something like bass that can occupy a very crucial part of the low end, that could prove problematic. Usually if I'm compressing bass, it's to bring out the sustain of the low end. So I'll typically set the release & the makeup gain first first to a place where I like how the low end is holding out, then dial in the attack to taste (usually on the medium-to-slow side). Grabby compression on bass can be fun in very specific instances, but I often find it distracting and fatiguing.

author: Lee Rouse
content: Always cleaning toms up to the hits. Also doing some low pass filter automation on them over the sustain to get rid of bleed from the cymbals.

author: Rollmottle
content:
> Like compressing a signal for it to be "even" (not that I would use a compressor for that) vs. using something like clip gain to make the signal even.

why wouldn't you use a compressor for that? that's what...they do?....clip gaining has the same effect, it's just manual and theoretically offers you more fine-grained control that a compressor wouldn't get you. you are still reducing the dynamic range in either scenario. you can draw volume automation on a signal that is identical to a theoretically transparent compressor's settings and the effect, sound, and dynamic range reduction should be exactly the same.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I really like mono reverbs for:

1. Vocal verb. It can just give the vocal it's own little space instead of spreading it out into the rest of everything in the sides. Just has a different feel, similar to "Mono drums" iMO.

2. Panning a reverb hard to one side, opposite of a dry signal. I.E. Electric guitar or synth.

Also, I use mono -> stereo reverbs a lot because when I was learning, I used the Lexicon PCM-70 a lot which was mono input. It also just made sense to me...not sure it matters a whole lot though ultimately. That is an aside to your question.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Try:
-compression on drum bus first before individual mics. I find compressing rooms on their own makes them sound small not big

-time delay rooms to make the room seem larger. This is a big albini trick 

-don’t be afraid to EQ the shit out of kick drum mics 

-don’t be afraid to add a lot of low end to the snare 

-transient designers on close mics can make shit punchy

author: Josh
content: Aye @BoozleBAM something that helped me really understand the attack and release times on compressors when I was starting, especially on drums (transient heavy material). Load up your plugin. Pin the threshold and ratio. You should be essentially redlining the gain reduction meter. Now put your release time to the fastest option and move that attack time around and you’ll hear exactly how the compressor is grabbing the source material. Once you like how it’s grabbing, adjust the release time to taste, back down that ratio and threshold and you’re off to the races. I still do this from time to time when I’m trying a new compressor to understand what we have going on under the hood.

author: oaklandmatt
content:

I just did a super dry vocal that had delay and verb like this. I used waves supertap with left and right slightly different but super short delay times. Almost phasing. Barely blended in at -20dB. Then I used Valhalla Vintage Verb on the small ambience setting at like 4%. It widens the vocal and gives it space without sounding at all "wet"

author: cian riordan
content: I think starting out with a modern compressor with all the parameters available to you will be more helpful in learning the concept. That way you can really understand the idea of a threshold, different attack/release combinations, and and compression ratios. Once you can start to understand what you're hearing, then you can apply that to other compressors that might have more fixed variables (LA2a, etc). I've always found overdoing it when you're first getting the settings will help you understand whats going on.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
EQ is powerful! 

Are you making the moves with elements in solo or in the context of the mix? Try out both. Solo is easier to hear what your doing to the thing, but eqing the element in context of the song/mix makes it easier to hear if your killing the vibe. I'd guess most people will encourage in-context EQing for this reason.

The reaper EQ is likely not the issue. Experiment with all the diff filters and shapes for sure! Best way to learn is to try it out. 

Also, eqing something and then undoing it later because it isnt better happens all the time while im mixing. Its great that you're double checking your moves later and trying to be objective about if its an improvement or not. Also- SOMETIMES its a boost not a cut thats needed. Too much bottom, maybe add some top or mids to balance it out instead of cutting bottom (just an example). See how that feels instead.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Of course depends on the tempo, part, sound of the drums, aesthetic of the track - but a few things that have worked in different scenarios for me:

Create the impression of some distance to walls by sending snare (start there, maybe add other mics) to a short stereo delay. Often something like 90ms on one side, 120ms on the other. Feel it out on one side, then add some time to the other.

Try adding some fake distance to your existing room mics with a simple delay with no feedback (there’s a Steve Albini drum video on YouTube where he demonstrates this). You can delay both sides equally, or solo one side, delay it til it feels good/sounds cool, then do the other. Anything from 12ms-around 23 seems to work. From there things start to become more like a slap, but than can be cool too.

Smash up your existing rooms a bit, or a lot. Omnipressor, Devil Loc, UAD Zener, decapitator, Rough Rider (free), Arousor/Distressor in nuke, Lo-Fi. 

Send to a gated verb - Cian shared a drum session a while back with a short VintageVerb preset that’s often useful. RMX16 Non-Lins can be good too, although it’s easy to bring things into 80s territory this way.

Send to a short room verb like ocean way, SP2016, Pro-R, Valhalla Room, Raum. Sometimes from close mics, sometimes from overheads, sometimes just slapping it straight on room mics. A little distortion (Decapitator, Devil Loc) after is often helpful.

With all of these solutions, the thing that seems to help them gel with the rest of the real kit is drum bus processing - compression and/or saturation.

author: Slow Hand
content: However, I find I get the most natural/full-sounding results if I varispeed the audio recording down to the desired pitch/formant and then use a granular algorithm to compress the audio back to it's original, faster, playback speed. It's more labor intensive, but the results usually sound more natural to my ears than doing a granular pitch-shift down.

author: peterlabberton
content: Annoying answer, but, it depends. (Ha! Stock answer for almost everything.) If the performance is uneven and really needs to be smoothed out, I might go for an 1176 at like 8:1 and catch loud parts. Then I might do a parallel comp (dbx 160, often), for more sustain and maybe snappiness. If certain notes are really poking out against others, as is often the case, I’ll ruthlessly eq them so they are balanced with Pro-Q3, instead of trying to solve that with more compression.

author: peterlabberton
content: Oh, echoing @cian riordan , the release feels especially important to me on bass gtr. I feel like it’s one of the few instances where I would regularly go with a longer release (I’m usually a big fast release dude). This would be if the bass is doing mostly whole notes, to get it to fill more of the measure. If I’m being specific about attack time... I’m usually (like almost always) getting the punch totally from the kick, so a faster attack usually feels pretty good to me, at least for the compressor not in parallel. And yes to the tonal change—I feel like usually I end up wanting to cut low end and add some kind of aggression, so compressors that go in that direction work well for me.

author: cian riordan
content:
Now that the basics are happening — kick and snare are really standing on their own two feet and in a place to drive the song — I’ll start bringing in other instruments in the mix and getting a sense of how things are adding up. Usually starting with bass, guitars, keys and finally vocals. Some people do vocals first — that’s never worked for me. Once you have a balance of the track, you can start really incorporating some of the overheads and room mics to give the drums more dimension and flavor. If the engineer really fucked the dog with the recording — or the room just sounds bad — I won’t spend too much time making them work… I’ll just get to manufacturing something that sounds cool. This could be leaning into a spring reverb, or a fun delay, or using other creative reverbs to get the drums have the space you want. I’m a big fan of un-natural sounding drums… distorted spring reverb panned hard left with a slap panned hard right? Why not! If someone serves you shit, shovel them ice cream.

Toms will literally be the last thing I work on. It’s just a matter of seeing what’s missing from the overall picture and filling in the blanks with the spot mics. I don’t like to trim the regions because I might find that when I’m gating, some of the bleed sounds good from the track. Sometimes, if the engineer did their job, the multi-mic recording will be really complete and will need the tom mics for the overall sound… so no gating at all. Again, all depends on what you’re working with.

Once I move on with the rest of my mix, I’ll find myself doing EQ moves on the drum buss and treating it more like one instrument to get other things happening in the mix… only doing small tweaks to the individual sounds.

I hope this all makes sense?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Neat question. If you're mixing in two channels (L/R) the headroom should be the same no matter where you pan it (with some caveats which we'll get to). If you have a kick drum panned dead center coming in at -6dB on your digital meter it's going to be coming in at -6 in both the L channel and -6 in the R channel. Each channel has it's own independent headroom that doesn't affect the other (until we add a limiter with linked channels), so let's simplify things a bit and mute the R channel for now:

Now you have your L channel with the kick panned "center" and the R channel is muted.  If you were to pan this kick to the hard left it would not affect the volume of the L channel at all. That's because the panning effect is created by subtracting gain from the R channel only. Making the kick sound like it's leaning to the left.

Now there's one big element I've left out so far, and that's *pan law*. Ableton Live has a -3dB pan law. This means that sounds panned to the center are reduced by 3dB. Because if a sound is being played at the same volume by both the L and R channels then their voltage will combine to create a sound that is louder than intended. So all DAWs and mixers compensate for this added loudness by turning down the gain of sounds as they are panned closer to the center (and shared between both speakers).

Since all modern DAWs and mixers have pan laws implemented, what happens when you now pan the kick hard left is that it ends up becoming 3dB louder than it was when it was panned in the center, because it is no longer being turned down by the pan law when it’s centered.

author: samvalentine
content:
My take away from that segment, if I'm remembering correctly, was that Jon doesn't use clip gain for 100% of his dynamic control. Instead, he carefully clip gains each transient/syllable/word/phrase into his dynamic processing (e.g., compressor, saturation, limiter), giving him precise control over how hard he hits the limiter.
I suppose another method to achieve similar results and that level of control would be to clip gain without processing, and then initiate a limiter (or your choice of dynamic processor) and automate the threshold and output to achieve the desired performance, but that seems like way more work to me.
I think Jon's method works well and I've been using it myself for a while. It would be interesting to hear of alternative workflows from the rest of the community though!

author: alex_epton
content: Do a quick balance first. With everything in. Don’t spend more than 15 mins on this. Check it on your aura tones too or whatever small alt speakers you use. Then put your two buss clipping/ limiting /any EQ you think you might need. Adjust this stuff til it sounds good and you’re hitting your target level. Get it as close as you can without touching your individual tracks. Then start dealing with little stuff on individual elements: Resonances. Masking. vocal sibilance. boomyness etc… needless to say you wanna sit down and tackle this with fresh ears. Your balance is probably the single most important thing you’re gonna do as a mixer. So do editing /cleaning clicks and vocal tuning on a different day

author: Slow Hand
content:
Perhaps I can address your issue at the source with how you have your Ableton compressor set up:

You're saying that you cannot get your 808 to duck low enough each time the kick hits. The first thing that stands out to me is that you're using a soft ratio. You need to crank that ratio up to at *least* a 4:1 ratio, but you might be even better off with an 8:1 or higher ratio. You need a high ratio to get the deeper ducking effect that it seems you're seeking.

Using a soft ratio will never get you a big duck unless you have the threshold pulled all of the way down. And even then it's probably going to have issues recovering correctly after each duck.

content:
If you don’t want to get too creative- I would use a dynamic eq dip around the “presence” frequencies, side chained to the vocal that comes in and overlaps it. 
So vocal “b” comes in on top of vocal “a” and like 3-5k gets ducked a few db. Or maybe the very top would work better than 3-5k… depends on the vocal.

author: CameronKuwada
content: This is an exercise I came up with when I first started ear training: Take a bright snap (one that has freqs up to 20k) and put it in a song/beat. Make three copies of the snap track and put one snap on each track, each spaced apart equally in space. In the first, put a lowpass up to 2.5k, in the 2nd, back up lowpass to 5k, in third, back up to 10k, and in the last, no low pass. as you play this track and cycle through snaps, you'll start to hear the differences in the various ranges from 2.5k - 10k and beyond (assuming good monitoring), and also how the equal loudness curve works.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Might be helpful to think of an EQ as a tool that simply boosts or cuts gain at specific frequencies using different filter types (i.e. bell, notch, HP, LP, etc...). HPF is still an EQ move. Not wholly accurate to conflate the two though they are used synonymously at times. Context dependent. Filter could be describing the shape of the EQ move being made. But if I said hey filter out everything below 100hz vs hey EQ out everything below 100hz - I mean the same thing. Might be a little more nuance to the history of the language used I could be missing; perhaps someone else could fill in. I think volcano has some non-linear harmonic / saturation component to it but I'm not super familiar with that plug.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
One of the reasons I think this way is because anytime you EQ something, you are introducing phase shifts around either side of the frequency you're using. I find low end to be particularly sensitive to phase shifts. Phase shifts blur sound slightly, which is particularly bad for the low end instrument that you want to be punchy and full. 

While EQ may boost your overall low end, often times you are losing punch and clarity at the same time.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Case dependent on song of course but generally 3 phases

1) Clean - clean up obvious issues, noise, excessive low end, overly roomy, overly dynamic (sometimes completely raw like this might have 20-30db or higher swings in dynamic range between sections) clip gain

2) Dynamics and EQ in track context - compress and EQ how you usually would for what's appropriate

3) Stylize - effects, saturation, stylized EQ

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When Jon receives a song to mix, there is almost always a lot of compression on the individual stems, especially drums and vocals. So he does more subtle moves to bring out the best in each mix. If you're recording stuff yourself, you will likely want to add a lot of compression to get the same modern, perceived loudness.

The fundamental thing to know is that "compression" simply means "reducing the dynamic range" (aka "compressing" the range of volume of your sound ). This can be achieved with "compressors" as well as "limiters," "saturators," "clippers," "distortion," and a number of other types of effects that do it in different ways (and may add other sonic characteristics to your sound).

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I got locked into 500 series while I was touring (for like 10 years,) and once I got my home studio setup I had everything hard wired, each mic had its own dedicated chain. All so I could work at the speed of my creativity focusing on parts & performance rather than capture & sonics. 

About 5 years in I was fast and savvy enough that I could let the Sonics play a bigger role without sacrificing momentum, so last year I installed a patch bay. Now just grabbing a mic to record takes a little longer, but I can do a lot more fun & creative work on the way in. 

So even if you decided to go 500 series, I’d argue that the modularity isn’t as big of a selling point on a microcosmic level. 

It might be worth thinking about the 500 series like a console, get yourself 8 Avedia Ma5s and do all your eq & compression in the box.

author: jantrit
content: There’s no one size fits all 100% of the time but my process looks something like this. 1.Phase! As others have said picking one mic as a phase constant and then checking other mics against this can yield great results. I don’t do a huge amount of mixing live drums that I didn’t track but this is usually the single biggest improvement. 2. I start with the over heads and work from there, usually filtering a touch of low end but I really like to keep these as a full picture of the whole kit. 3. Subtle saturation, I find an instance of Saturn works wonders on some kicks and a lot of other drum sources. 4. Gating and compression, can work wonders to clean up a kick or snare, always checking to make sure that any processing is actually an improvement. 5. Additive eq, boost those pleasing freqs! I should note that 95% of this whole process happens while listening to everything, I don’t usually solo any one element to do any of this (except to start the gating maybe)

author: cian riordan
content: If you have a mono sound on a mono track, it will sound mono. If you have mono sound on a stereo track, it will still sound mono. You can add delays, phasing, pitch shifting, etc to make it sound 'wide'... and yes, it will theoretically take up more space in the mix. As far as taking up more headroom, there's just too many variables to figure out there. But if you have the mono sound on a mono track, and the mono sound on a stereo track, with modern pan laws, they would both take up the same headroom.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So to answer your question, yes, a sound will technically take up more headroom when hard-panned (or spread), because the pan law makes it a little louder when panned to the extremes. However because this also makes the sound perceptually louder you’re likely to turn the sound down a little bit to compensate for the boost in volume, thus buying you back the headroom you’d have lost.

I may have missed a few things. Other DAWs use other pan laws, and admittedly I'm not up to date on the minutiae of it all. So don’t hesitate to amend, or correct me on this stuff, folks.

author: David Fuller
content: Some DAWs like Pro Tools can actually change pan law. PT can do -2.5dB, -3dB, -4.5dB, and -6dB. Mixes sound different with different pan laws - and I'll bounce some stuff real quick to demonstrate.

author: oaklandmatt
content: the main thing is that in order to get that modern high-end attack from individual drums, you need to do a lot of eq boosting. this causes the cymbals that are picked up by the close mics to be super loud. if you gate those close mics (or even better: just mute the audio around each hit by hand) you have a lot more control with how much you can process and control those individual drums

author: Zakhiggins
content: Also If you set the ratio to max and bring the threshold all the way down, it'll then become really obvious what attack and release are doing to the sound, so set them the way you like, then bring the ratio back, as you do that it'll be apparent what that's doing too - then set the threshold to taste and it'll be very obvious what your compressor is doing

author: ALXCPH

author: oaklandmatt
content: @sloth the reason is use clip gain is so you're not relying on the limiter or compressor to level out the sound. rather, you're using the limiter or compressor for the SOUND it creates. if you want that super compressed sound (or even that lightly compressed sound) of an actual compressor or limiter, you'll often get better results if the signal going into it is evened out a bit. this used to be solved mostly by great mic technique, where a singer would lean back on big notes and whatnot. but these days by using clip gain to even out the sound before it hits your dynamic processing, you can actually more fully lean into the SOUND of the compressor or limiter that comes after it.

author: Will Melones
content:
Oh yeah, for sure. It’s easy to overdo it, and satisfying enough that sometimes you don’t know in the moment.

Ultimately you can be 100% in the right speaker or 100% in the left speaker, and pushing beyond that is tempting the gods. As far as I can conceive it, any process that attempts to widen a signal that’s already entirely decorrelated must have the potential to reintroduce some correlation. Thinking again of the ping pong delay, is there really anything wider than that?

I was doing a lot of M/S mix buss widening stuff a few years ago, and I realized that it could do some pretty weird shit to panned vocals and the like. While it feels like you can just ‘turn up the sides’, you’re really doing something unnatural to the center, too, and the relationship between channels. Like you’re choosing select bits of a sound to turn up, but only the bits of that sound that don’t have anything in common with the other speaker. This is a lot of rambling just to say that there’s clearly a point of diminishing returns, and maybe the solution is to pan something else less wide to create contrast.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
Bit of an aside (still bus related) and not sure if this is the best way of doing it, but I tend to route all musical elements (non-drums and percussion) to a bus, all drums and percussion to a second bus, and all vocals to a third bus. 

I then have a further bus where I bring the musical elements together with the drums and perc, so “instrumental”.

And then my final bus which I label “all” that pushes through to the mix bus.

This way I have plenty of options for automation, levelling, compression, and even FX like whacking EchoBoy or the Echorec on it and going nuts for transitions and bridges etc.

It’s possibly not the best way of doing it but it works great for me at the mo. My template for writing / prod and mixing is just set up that way now.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Here goes…
Million ways to skin this cat. I’ll give you food for thought.

1. At least double track. My personal goal, is to get the sound to be as awesome and huge and perfect with 1 pair of guitar tracks doubled, with 1 mic on an amp. That’s the ideal scenario for me. That said There are people that sum 4 mics down to 1 signal on a mixer and it sounds amazing.  

2. The more performances  you add of the same part, the more blurry it will sound.if you need different textures, consider recording a DI so it can be blended in with your amp in any manner of your choice, either reamping, distorting with a plugin, whatever. (Check phase)

3. I like when the left and right are *subtly* different, no drastically different. You hear “the left and right being different is what makes something wide”
This is true. But I loathe when it’s so different it feels lopsided.

How do we address this? 

-double track using the same guitar so the tuning and intonation is most similar 

-change the amp head but keep the same cabinet/speaker so the overall EQ is similar but my the gain structure is different

If you use 2 different guitars, consider the scale lengths. This will change subtle intonation things, for better or worse.

author: Rob Domos
content:
If it’s the hissing kind of noise that you get more of when you switch from condensers to dynamics and ribbons, then it’s not the kind of noise that is coming from the room. 

In rooms the main things you would be concerned about would be reflection (which you fix with treatment) and mechanical noise from things like computer fans, clocks, etc. and condenser mics would pick those kinds of sounds up more, not less. 

Any unison pre in the Apollo should be plenty low noise to not bother you on your condenser mics. I agree with others that not using any unison pre will make the noise floor lower, but I disagree with them in that I think using the unison pres is a pretty good idea often. 

That said, if you’re struggling with noise, definitely try not compressing on the way in because compressors are only going to raise the noise floor. 

On dynamic mics and ribbon mics, you can decrease your noise floor pretty considerably by picking up a cloudlifter and throwing that in the chain. 

If you do all of the above and still have a high noise floor then either the Apollo is broken (which is pretty unlikely), or your microphone is picking up mechanical noise from your air conditioning, computer fan, refrigerator, etc. if those are the issue, then tackle the issue there. Turn off the A/C, turn off the fridge, turn off the LED lights, etc and see what you hear.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Also beyond “fixing” the best thing i ever learned for drum mixing was drum bus compression, and using saturation on close mics.

My usual chain is this:
All kick and snare mics get some sort of eq if needed. Then I’ll put fab filter Saturn 2 and saturate the high end at around 700hz.

The I’ll bus all the drums to an aux. then I’ll usually do this:
Tape saturation (waves J37)
Parallel drum compression with a mix knob (fast release, slow attack) I use the kush audio AR-1, I used to use the waves abbey road mastering plugin. 

Sometimes I’ll use wavesfactory Spectre to boost highs and lows after all that. Maybe soundtoys Sie-Q to boost midrange.

author: cian riordan
content:
Template:
I’ve attached a slimmed down version of my mix template with all of the drum bussing. This has evolved over many years and has taken many forms, but it’s really just a good starting point for me and speeds up my workflow quite a bit. I’ve got three main busses that feed into a master drum buss. ‘DRUM SUB’ is my uncompressed (or lightly compressed) buss. ‘DRUM PAR’ is my heavily compressed buss, and ‘DRUM DIST’ is my parallel distortion buss. I don’t necessarily always use these, but having them ready to go makes it easier to quickly audition different ideas. Sometimes I’ll duplicate one or two of them to get another flavor involved. Again, everything to taste. 

Also in the template are some very basic aux’s I find myself using often. There are two parallel SansAmp busses. I have two because often times if I use one on the kick drum, it rarely works for the snare drum, so I have a second one ready to go. There’s also a ‘SNARE SLAP’ and ‘SNARE GATE VERB’ that rarely get used but if I need to inject a little mojo, they’re a good starting point.

The ‘D SUB TRIM’ is just a master fader controlling everything going into the bussing, so if I get a little overzealous with level, I can manage the gain staging quickly without having volume automation grouped. These three (sometimes more) busses then feed into the final ‘DRUM MSTR’ , where I’ll do final overall EQ tweaks and level adjustments.

author: cian riordan
content:
I'll gate everything with the Pro-G. Usually as tight as I can while sometimes automating threshhold to make sure ghostnotes don't get lost. I'll peel back the ratio once I have everything triggering properly to let some bleed in to taste. Sometimes I'll only gate 2-3 dB to just get something to pop. Sometimes its in a vaccum.
I will very rarely compress individual drum mics. And I pray that the recording engineer didn’t either. I like most of my compression to come from the busses. It sounds more natural to my ear and allows you to get away with a more compressed, exciting sound than just whacking the close mics. I’ll find at the beginning my drum mixes will be very ‘pokey’ — I want each drum to sound explosive and over the top. That way when i start compressing them, they maintain their transient quality when they start getting dynamically reduced.

I’m always cutting tons of 250-350 out of the kick drums and trying to manufacture any attack with saturation instead of EQ. Having a SansAmp or a Saturn plugin adding high end always sounds more natural to me than just additive EQ. I’m always very wary of the 2-5khz region, and find even-order harmonics are the best bet to fill in the blanks there.

I tend to like my snare drums warm, so often low-shelving down the super low end and keeping the 150-300 ‘boosh’ intact. I try to avoid using HPF on drum mics because at this point, things should be relatively in phase, so if I put a filter on, it’s going to throw the whole kaboodle off whack. Shelves are your friend here. And same as with the kick drums re: adding high end — I’m wary off adding the snap in the 2-5khz range, I’ll try and have the body of the snare drum really singing so I only have to add a little bit of top end, often above 5khz just for some air.

author: Zack Hames
content: Compression is knocking level down at a certain threshold. Dynamic EQ can be used to compress or expand very specific EQ ranges at a certain threshold. It's like super focused multiband compression with the ability to expand or compress.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i actually don't know what this means. maybe someone on here can come explain. "gain movement" is "more transparent than compression" doesn't make sense to me. seems like the same thing.

other than that dynamic eq and multiband compression are essentially the same. there are multiband compressors that will split the signal into multiple bands by default, so you're gonna get some phase shift between the bands, even if you're not compressing. but some plugins you can disengage the bands so depending on the plug-in architecture, you'd presumably not be getting the phase shift if you're turning off the band splitting

author: Maxim
content:
Yeah to me visually it makes a lot of sense that there is a difference between the two in terms of processing. But the different use cases seem pretty obvious too:

"If you want to attenuate a specific “problem” frequency or small range of frequencies, a dynamic EQ would be your best bet. The option to have narrower bands allows for this kind of focused attenuation.

Conversely, if you’re trying to control larger areas of the frequency spectrum, a multiband compressor works well. Also the non-linear way a compressor attenuates signal can add character to a signal. If you don’t need the surgical control, but want some subtle sonic coloration, a multiband compressor can be a better choice than a dynamic EQ."

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Maxim I think I understand your question a little better now. I believe you're thinking of compression as both A) reducing the volume and B) applying make-up gain. To achieve this with a dynamic EQ you have to set the amount of gain reduction but then you *also* need to boost the volume of that EQ band (like it was makeup gain, which it is).

Did I understand correctly?

content:
No, I'm thinking more in terms of dynamic range. Like compressing a signal for it to be "even" (not that I would use a compressor for that) vs. using something like clip gain to make the signal even. Both get you a similar result but with a different sound in the end. 

I was wondering if this applies to Dynamic EQ as well. As I see an EQ as a gain tool for certain frequencies.

author: Maxim
content: If you imagine a waveform with peaks you can gain the peaks down. You can compress them (where they are "squeezed" together in my mind) or you can do things like hard clipping where the peak is shaved off.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- **Higher sample rates reduce aliasing.** There is effectively no difference between 44.1 and 48k here but a meaningful difference at 96k and above. Aliasing is caused by non linear processes like distortion, and dynamics processing (compressor or limiter). Lots online about what it is and why it happens but you can sum it up by saying it’s an inharmonic, digital sounding hash that can feel bright but in a kind of ugly way (but remember sometimes ugly is good)
- **Higher sample rates reduce the impact of Anti Imaging and Anti Aliasing filters in AD to DA converters.** Filtering is necessary for accurate capture and replay of analog signals, and it in the early days of digital it used to be a real challenge. Now it’s basically a solved problem, but if you are doing acoustic music, with delicate transient information there is still a small but real advantage to higher rates
- **Higher sample rates reduce overshoot and inter sample peaks on limiters.** This really only matters if you are sending your loud mixes directly to release, otherwise your mastering girl or guy should handle that

author: cian riordan
content:
This is a very broad question with many different answers, but I think the easiest way to sum up the concept of ‘gain staging’ is simply figuring out what level every ‘device’ is expecting and/or which level is ideal to get the results you want. These ‘devices’ can be a plugin, a piece of hardware, an A/D/A converter, an auxiliary bus, a mix bus, etc.

In analog world… there might be fathomable difference when a compressor or amplifier receives -10dBVU vs +10 dBVU. Accounting for these differences would be considered gain staging — and you’d be looking for what gets the ideal sound out of your box.

In digital world… some plugins may react similarly and others may not care if you’re sending -6dBFS or -0.01dBFS. It’s usually case by case as there are myriad plugins. You also need to consider what level the plugin is sending signal out — as this will affect how the next plugin processes the audio, or how much headroom it has to work with. Let’s say I’m sending signal out of a compressor plugin into an EQ plugin — and lets say I’m using the compressor to beef up mean volume of the signal and then I want to EQ some more low end into the signal after the fact. Well, I’m going to be adding gain in the compressor and then the level going into the EQ will be hotter than originally intended. Id want to trim down the output of the compressor (or the input of the EQ) so you have headroom to be able to boost those frequencies without clipping the output of the EQ. In a 32-bit floating mixer like Pro Tools, these issues become less audible as the mixer has higher headroom than its indicating, but you never actually know — and it’s best to just stick to the parameters that you have control over. If you were to do this same function with an analog compressor and EQ, there would be very noticeable distortion if you didn’t stage the gain properly.

author: ehutton21
content:
I wrote in my notes from the Bainz episode that the way each guest/mixer talks about gainstaging the various tracks of a mix, it definitely is the mixer’s version of a “business mission statement,” which @Slow Hand alludes to with the idea of talking about how one choice ripples to inform all of our other decisions. Gainstaging sets the record up to show off its best qualities—and are those qualities in the low end of a booming bass synth and the natural silky quality of the vocalist, or maybe you want the mid range to feel really detailed yet cohesive and warm. 

Understanding this, for me, made the finishing process that Jon talks about make sense. Level setting inherently overlaps with the kind of decision making process of EQing, which is something you can probably understand best from this clip of Bainz talking about how he can get a vocal to be so upfront in his mixes because he’s surgical in what he keeps in there. The way I understood it, he’s cleaned up the vocal a ton, set the levels of his tracks by what feels important to bring to the forefront for the listener, and then he uses those levels to inform his EQ moves throughout.

https://www.instagram.com/tv/CkSeHgrosyx/?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y=

author: ehutton21
content:
What Jon talks about doing with headroom, for me, didn’t make sense until I heard what Bainz said in different incarnations on different occasions. 

By turning everything down 6 DBs midway through or near the end of the mix process, and then slowly pushing levels up to set your “balance” and then taking an EQ and using it very deliberately, you get a real gut check on “have I been deliberate with what I’m emphasizing for the listener.”

author: Rob Domos
content:
Just reading through what you and @river were talking about and I’d like to balance this perspective out a little bit.

While I’d agree that things like midside EQ can make things sound strange in a way I don’t like, I’m not shying away from decoupling the mids from the sides in general or saying M/S = Bad. Turning down the M channel on elements that I want to have be more background surrounding elements with a plugin like CenterOne is actually one of my most common mix moves and it sounds great.

A good friend of mine who has made one of my favorite mixes of all time constantly talks about his use of M/S processing. I don’t do much M/S other than levels and stereo imagining, but my boi does regularly and he sounds great. 

All that to say: River,  It’s worth being careful and listening to what could be getting fucked up in your midside processing, I wouldn’t be M/S EQing personally, and you should generally only do M/S moves with speakers and generally not with headphones, but that doesn’t mean that you should shy away from M/S all together if it sounds really good to you. Lots of great engineers are using it all the time.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This isn’t for everyone, but a few big mixers like this technique. 

After you clean & clip gain, (RX is super helpful for plosives, mouth noises, de essing,) this is one of the only ways I know to take a vocal from raw to sounding like it was tracked well. 

The concept is mostly about balancing a spitty compressor like an 1176 and a slower/warmer compressor like a Fairchild, and then bussing both of those to a new aux, then eq’ing compressing saturating de essing like that was the vocal you weee given in the first place.

author: tinkerjef
content:
hi all, new guy here, and I guess I have a pretty simple question, and might be kinda loaded, but what does absolute phase shift sound like?

Ive been learning a heck of a lot from the LWMR series on yt, and I've been approaching my mixing philosophy from the lens of an electronics designer.

It's pretty well accepted in the electronics/audio research world that absolute phase shifts aren't really audible, and that the moment audio is played in a space that has reflections, it's imperceptible. The only real way to hear a phase shift is to be in an anechoic chamber and play a specialized test signal (like a sine wave with timed phase shift pulses to create a slight warble)

I get how on individual tracks if you EQ something, the phase shift can affect how that track interacts with another track when summed, but I often hear that for example, Jon puts a 16k boost then a 27k low pass on the master that creates a phase bump that he likes. Which theoretically shouldn't be audble... Shouldn't it be some other reason like the VT5 saturating a special way?

author: kidcutler
content: Not sure if it answers the question but he also used the vintage eq from ozone for the same trick on vocals, the ozone doesn’t go as high so i think it doesn’t work on the mixbus but it may be a “pleasurable” phase thing

author: cy (sigh)
content:
there's are people way more versed on this but an absolute phase shift would be a polarity flip or 180 degrees. besides very specific filter types any EQ move is usually changing the phase to PART  of the signal to get the new freq response. it is not absolute 

EQ changes the phase to change the frequency (not the other way way around).

author: tinkerjef
content: Hmm I think if I were to reframe my question, is how come phase shift is said to be the reason behind so many things, when in reality, simple eq phase shifts aren’t actually audible

author: tinkerjef
content: Hmm well doesn’t EQ change amplitude at a given frequency and the by product is a phase shift

author: tinkerjef
content: Yeah this is what I was thinking as well on individual tracks. It’s just say you EQ your master. Does the phase shift have anything audible to do with the sound? (Also thanks for the reply!)

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Phase coherence as it relates to speakers vs how an eq shifts phase within a single track in mixing are two entirely different worlds. Not worth considering how they relate. 

For what it’s worth, I almost never pay attention to how an eq effect phase except for when filtering out low end, as it actually does create a resonant peak just above the filter point. 

Otherwise the only question that really needs answering is “is this better for the track?”

author: tinkerjef
content: Hmm could you speak more to why they’re completely different worlds? From my POV, phase shifts are phase shifts, they don’t vary by what condition they’re in. The xover in a speaker are filters that impart the same high and low pass phase shifts in an EQ (and hence the same phase response and group delay). But I digress, that wasn’t my original question lol. Original question was whether phase shift from EQ on the master is audible?

author: tinkerjef
content: And I guess if I were to choose a specific example, it’d be Jon saying boosting 16k and low passing 27k creating a pleasing phase bump, where psychoacoustic research tells us phase shifts like that aren’t audible

author: spectrummasters
content:
I expect this will be common knowledge to the vets but might be new to others (as it is to me ) and thought it looked a fascinating technique im going to try and wanted to share :

I just watched Steve albini describe how he would use an equalizer in a feedback loop to generate a resonant frequency, then blend that tone with the original kick drum signal to allow him to choose a complementary pitch/note with the eq and via the feedback loop also add sustain to taste . 
If others know a better routing please do correct me : i think he sent the kick to the eq as an aux (not an insert), then brings the return back in a new channel , then sends that channel back to the eq again, creating the feedback loop and blends that into the mix to support the untreated kick. 
I feel this is a little different to regular ITB parallels or VOG processing in that he’s creating a feedback loop/resonance at a chosen note …sort of like synthesising an 808 ? Kinda genius. 
(This is happening OTB with hardware )

author: masteredbyjack
content:
To illustrate a good example of the difference and why (guessing) Jon would want to clip rather than do this (which would control the transients as you describe)

If you use a long look ahead, call it a limiter with a long look ahead. That will let the processor know about the transient well before it hits the GR circuit, thus avoiding distortion/harmonics (of course there still could be some artifacts). But even though there will be samples at the threshold, it won’t be a straight line waveform as if you clipped it. It is pushing the waveform down. The waveform itself is actually changed still, so it is not exact but it’s different than clipping.

A clipper just squares it off. Hence harmonics.

This is why you can limit/compress an instrument like piano, which has a tendency to hear distortion easily, when clipping it would be a disaster (unless you are going for that)
